author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: 17 schools in Conn. on lockdown after 2 bomb threats
text:
nbc connecticut Seventeen schools in Fairfield, Conn., are on lockdown after police received three threatening phone calls. Police are swarming more than a dozen Connecticut schools after receiving two bomb threats and a harrowing call from a man saying he was headed to an elementary school with a rifle, officials said.
It's unclear if the calls were credible, but they led to the lockdown early Friday of all 17 schools in Fairfield, Conn., as authorities investigate, according to Fairfield Public Schools.
"The police have been unable to confirm the threat at this time. But they are taking them seriously. Please do not come to the schools," it said in a warning on its website.
An armed man phoned police shortly before 9 a.m. saying he was on his way to Holland Hill Elementary School with an M16 rifle, Fairfield police Lt. James Perez told the Hartford Courant.
Authorities also received calls of bombs at Fairfield Ludlowe High School and pipe bombs at Fairfield Warde High School, the newspaper reported.
nbc connecticut Seventeen schools in Fairfield, Conn., are on lockdown after police received three threatening phone calls. All the students and staff at the schools are "safe and secure," Fairfield Police Chief Gary Macnamara said at a news conference.
Parents were asked to stay home but could report to the Fairfield Prep parking lot with concern.
Fairfield police officers have requested reinforcements from neighboring towns.
This is a developing story. Check back for more updates.
